body_html:
yes, you can even import nccl ... doesn't throw until you call into the .so.
import tensorflow.contrib.nccl as nccl
dir(nccl)
['builtins', 'cached', 'doc', 'file', 'loader', 'name', 'package', 'path', 'spec', 'all_max', 'all_min', 'all_prod', 'all_sum', 'broadcast']

All unit tests are passing for gpu as well.

The reason why it doesn't throw is here: windows don't have all the loadable ops yet so the loader has a special case for windows to return None instead of throwing:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/util/loader.py#L52

import tensorflow.contrib.nccl as nccl

['builtins', 'cached', 'doc', 'file', 'loader', 'name', 'package', 'path', 'spec', 'all_max', 'all_min', 'all_prod', 'all_sum', 'broadcast']
All unit tests are passing for gpu as well.
The reason why it doesn't throw is here: windows don't have all the loadable ops yet so the loader has a special case for windows to return None instead of throwing:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/util/loader.py#L52
body:
yes, you can even import nccl ... doesn't throw until you call into the .so.
import tensorflow.contrib.nccl as nccl
dir(nccl)
['__builtins__', '__cached__', '__doc__', '__file__', '__loader__', '__name__', '__package__', '__path__', '__spec__', 'all_max', 'all_min', 'all_prod', 'all_sum', 'broadcast']

All unit tests are passing for gpu as well.

The reason why it doesn't throw is here: windows don't have all the loadable ops yet so the loader has a special case for windows to return None instead of throwing:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/util/loader.py#L52
